author: Kelly Kazek | kkazek@al.com
title: 12 of Alabama's oldest surviving structures: From lighthouse to church to courthouse
text:
Comments 
While researching 13 of Alabama's oldest homes, I came across more of the state's earliest structures. Click here to see the oldest homes. If you know of additional or conflicting information for any of these buildings or dates, email kkazek@al.com . Or submit suggestions for other historical structures. 
Oldest Tavern Lucas Tavern Old Alabama Town, Montgomery, Ala. 
Built circa-1810s, according to Old Alabama Town , although some sources say 1818. Moved from its original location east of town that was once along the Old Federal Road. Now a museum as part of Old Alabama Town. Click here to see more of the state's oldest surviving taverns and stagecoach inns . 
Oldest Methodist Church Cambridge United Methodist 14888 Cambridge Lane, Athens, Ala. 
Built in 1818, Confederate troops used the church as a base before Union troops damaged it in 1865. It was restored in 1873. Click here to see the state's earliest churches. 
Oldest Baptist Church Indian Springs Baptist Located beside Highway 21, 2.5 miles south of McWilliams, Ala. 
Built in 1825. RuralSWAlabama.org says: "The original wood-frame building survived virtually unchanged â€“ with no modern conveniences." 
Oldest Jail The Old Rock Jail Linn Street, Rockford, Ala. 
The Old Rock Jail, built in 1825, is a museum and is open for tours by appointment or on certain occasions, according to toureastalabama.com . It is listed on the National Register of Historic Places. Click here to see 12 of the state's oldest surviving jails . 
First Public School Barton Academy 504 Government St., Mobile, Ala. 
Constructed from 1836 to 1839, the school was designed by architects James H. Dakin, Charles B. Dakin, and James Gallier Sr. In 2009, Barton Academy was listed as one of Alabama's Places in Peril and is in need of restoration. 
Oldest Courthouse Somerville Courthouse 24 Courthouse Square, Somerville, Ala. 
Built in 1837. Somerville was the first seat of Morgan County and court was held there until the seat moved to Decatur in 1891. It is now a museum and community building. However, it has been closed temporarily, according to the Town of Somerville website. "Until further notice, the Historic Somerville Courthouse is closed to the public due to safety issues with the floors." Click here to see more of Alabama's earliest courthouses. Oldest Bank 925 Bank Street, Decatur, Ala. 
Built in 1833, the Old State Bank is listed on the National Register of Historic Places. It is now a museum and has also been the site of several paranormal investigations. 
Oldest Municipal Building Marion City Hall Polk Street, Marion, Ala. 
The Old Marion City Hall was built in 1832 and used until 1968. The building was later moved to the campus of Marion Military Institute and restored, according to the City of Marion website. "In 1988, it became the Alabama Military Hall of Honor Museum displaying portrait plaques of inductees and military artifacts." 
Oldest Covered Bridge Coldwater Bridge Oxford Lake Park, Oxford, Ala. 
Built between 1839 and 1850, the 60-foot span initially crossed an inlet in Oxford Lake but was moved to Oxford Lake Park in 1990. Click here to read about Alabama's surviving covered bridges. 
Oldest Ballpark in the U.S. Rickwood Field 1137 Second Ave West, Birmingham, Ala. 
Built in 1910 for the Birmingham Barons and Black Barons Negro Leagues baseball teams, Rickwood Field is thought to be the oldest surviving ballpark in the country. As such, it has been used to film period sports films, most recently the Jackie Robinson biopic "42." 
Oldest Lighthouse Sand Island Light Sand Island, Mobile County, Ala. 
Built on a tiny, eroding island, Sand Island Lighthouse at the southernmost tip of Alabama is endangered. The original light at the site was destroyed in 1863 by Civil War fire and was rebuilt ca. late1870s-1884. Plans were made for restoration but it was damaged again by Hurricanes Ivan and Katrina. 
Oldest Postal Facility Mooresville Post Office Corner Lauderdale and High Streets, Mooresville, Ala. 
Built circa-1840 of sawmilled lumber, the Mooresville Post Office is still in operation, making it the oldest continually operating postal service in Alabama.
